column4: Hi, I have a question about moving an existing Ubuntu install to a new system -- I just built a new computer with completely different parts than my previous one. In my new computer, I have an AMD Phenom II X6 CPU, an EVGA GTX 580 "Superclocked" GPU, and 16GB of Corsair Dominator DDR3-1600 RAM. In my old system, I had an Intel Core2 Quad Q6600 CPU, and ATI Radeon X1950 GPU, and 2GB of DDR2 PC2-8500 Crucial Ballistix T

racer RAM. My new system is liquid cooled, and the CPU averages 18 degrees Celsius, with very minimal CPU usage. I simply installed my old HDD in my new system, without reinstalling Ubuntu. I'm running 10.10 with all the latest updates, and the proprietary Nvidia driver. Despite all this, my old system 'felt' significantly faster than my new one, except for OpenGL performance. Is there any way to reconfigure Ubuntu to

work better with my new hardware? I'm not sure what could be wrong. It's worth nothing that every time Ubuntu boots up, it says "Too many connections." on the screen, and kernel modesetting does not work.
Please don't flood; use http://paste.ubuntu.com to paste; don't use Enter as punctuation.
